You have the farmer who cannot sell it, and you have people here hungry who cannot get it, while those who can get it must pay an enormous price.

Potatoes in Dublin are selling at one shilling a stone, whereas in the country I do not suppose that they can sell them for threepence. They cannot feed them to pigs, because pigs are nearly useless at present. The Minister should apply himself to that problem. He should give a lead. We have the ability to collect money, but we have no ability to stimulate production in any way. It has been taught to us here for generations that we are purely an agricultural country and that the moment we leave agriculture we are lost, because God Almighty never intended us for anything else. We have been told that if we enter into any industrial production we must of necessity be a failure. I think that the Minister for Agriculture is convinced that under no conditions, certainly not under present conditions, can he make a success of agriculture. We will not be able to make a success of agriculture until we develop other industries.

I believe that direct assistance to farmers will not do anything, and that the assistance that farmers can get, to do them any good, must be indirect assistance. That is largely the reason that you find all through the country such indifference amongst all farmers. There is no doubt that there is that indifference. They were indifferent about this Budget. I suppose they heaved a sigh of relief when they found that there was no increase in taxation. That, however, is all; they are not jubilant about it. All that they say to-day is: “This is stabilised. Here we are. We are not going to have it any higher, but certainly we are not going to have it any lower, nor is any effort going to be made to increase or encourage our production.” That is the reason that all through the country during the last winter the agricultural classes, with their highly paid and efficient instructors, were so poorly attended. I believe that all that demoralisation and indifference arises absolutely from the system of taxation which we have inherited but from which we are making no effort whatever to get away. When we come to examine the system of taxation and when we read its history we generally find that it sprang up because of some abnormal conditions, because there was a big war or something of that kind. When money was wanted in a hurry Ministers of Finance found that this was a very convenient and handy method of getting it. There was no trouble about it so far as they were concerned. There it has remained. That is the present system and no change has been made.

Local rates, for instance, are nothing but a tax, and every effort is being made to collect them to-day, so much so that if they are not paid and if a man is not capable of paying them immediately, he is not allowed to make an effort to pay. No heed whatever is paid to the question of production there. It means that he is locked up and held there until such time as somebody may lend him money to pay his rates. That local tax is raised on a basis which undoubtedly is not equitable, and, furthermore, a good deal of ordinary taxation is still raised on that basis. You find that our main producers, the farmers, are taxed, either centrally or nationally, on that basis, which is completely inequitable, but no consideration can apparently be given to it. This year we have come to the point of stabilising that. I hope that the Minister only means that the amount he wants, between £24,000,000 and £26,000,000, is stabilised, and that he does not mean to stabilise this particular system. Before he does so, I hope he will have an inquiry into the whole subject in order to try and find means to stimulate production rather than to stimulate what is, to all intents and purposes, luxury.

There is no doubt that the poorest people in this country pay the heaviest amount of taxation. There is no use in saying that such taxation is based on their capacity to pay. The capacity of some of them to pay is practically nothing, but still, if they want to live at all, they must try and find some means of paying such taxes. In general, such tax is paid before they start to earn or produce anything. You have, for instance, the tobacco tax. That was mentioned by the Minister yesterday, and there is no doubt that it is a very handy way of getting money. From his point of view the Minister is perfectly right, because he has not the slightest trouble with it. Before such commodity is removed from bond, if it is home produced, the manufacturer has to pay 6/8, even if he only takes out one pound of tobacco. The man has to pay that 6/8 before he manufactures anything. He is taxed long before the article is produced and much longer before it is consumed. On the other hand, we have imported tobacco and the tax is paid by the manufacturer on the leaf. What is the position with the consumer? He pays practically half the value of the article he consumes directly to the Government, and it is collected by the shopkeeper. That is a very economic system and there is no doubt that it is quite right because it saves the State the cost of collection.

Who are the people who have to pay that tax and who have no means of avoiding it? They are the very poorest people we have. There is no difference made, no preference given to them whatsoever. This commodity was called a luxury, and that was the ostensible reason it was taxed, but that was not the real reason. The real reason was that it was simply a handy means of raising revenue. I believe that on certain classes of that commodity consumed by the very poor, the Minister should consider giving some form of rebate. It would be very easy to differentiate, as the very poor generally smoke the strong class of tobacco. I think the Minister might consider giving some small rebate on that strong class of tobacco, if not this year certainly in next year's Budget, and so afford these people an opportunity of indulging in that little luxury, if he calls it a luxury.

I made the statement that tariffs were to a large extent investments. and if we ask farmers in this country to pay duty on foreign goods and if the proceeds of that duty are invested in the development of production in factories in this country, the farmers are sure to get the benefit of such a tariff at some future date. Not alone that, but according to the policy which we are pursuing to-day it will be necessary to provide some form of production in which the sons and daughters of farmers will be absorbed. If the tariff or duty is properly imposed and properly adjusted so that it will become an investment, the Minister for Finance gets no benefit. It is then perfectly right. The proceeds are invested in that industry so that it may be developed and its produce efficiently marketed, and finally in order that the sons and daughters of the small farmers, a class which is rapidly increasing, may be engaged in that industry. Whether the Minister, this Government, or any other Government that may follow them, like it or not, they will be faced with that problem, because we have innumerable small farmers springing up in each county. These small farmers will eventually have children. They will have sons and daughters who will be faced with the problem of securing some position in life. Certainly the thirty acres of land or so which the father of a family may possess will not be sufficient to divide amongst his children.

Unless we continue the policy of emigration there is no other avenue of employment left to these people. Unless we make a determined attempt to absorb them in industry emigration is bound to continue. There is no other means of preventing it. We are not wealthy enough to give them gratuities or bonuses, and no matter how many people of the wealthy class we may encourage to come in here, they will not be able to absorb them as servants, grooms or chauffeurs. There seems to be no means of keeping them here in Ireland except through the establishment of other industries. The agricultural industry alone is not able to provide for them. It cannot of itself employ the number of people that we have been hitherto persuaded it could employ. For instance, in our present condition. I take it that we have more cattle and sheep in this country per 100 of the population than in any other country in Europe. We have even more than they have in Canada and the United States, and still we are in the condition in which we now find ourselves. Emigration continues, absolute poverty exists, and no attempt is made to increase production.

Speaker.P: I desire, speaking on the general Resolution, to make some inquiries in regard to the tariffs already in force, and particularly in regard to the tariff on wearing apparel. I would like if the Minister would tell us what was the intention of the Dáil when the tariff on wearing apparel was imposed. Recently a case came under my personal notice regarding material brought from England for cricket— batting gloves, wicket - keeping gloves and leg pads. These were held up at the port of Waterford as wearing apparel. I was notified about their arrival, and I went down and saw them. I had subsequently an interview with some official of the Department of Finance, but I heard nothing more about it until I heard that if these articles were not removed within a certain date they would be sent back to England, and they have been sent back. Was it ever the intention of the Minister or the House to rate articles of that description as wearing apparel? We have been told that these are borderline cases, but it is left to the Commissioners or some of their officials at ports down the country to say whether this tax is to be imposed or not. Are they to be the judges? Surely the House had some definite object in mind when imposing the tariff, and surely the Minister who proposed it had also something definite in his mind? If it is to be the law that these articles should be subject to a tariff, let that be stated definitely, but if it is not, what is the use of holding up articles which it was never intended should be taxed? I think I am voicing the opinion of the House when I say that it was not intended to rate these articles as wearing apparel.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. Hennessy Mr. M. Hennessy
Speaker.P: What are they?
Batting gloves, partly rubber and partly leather.
Are they worn?

They are. Another thing which comes under the heading of furniture is the ordinary zine bucket with a small bit of timber in the centre of the handle. They are sent back or charged as wooden furniture. There are some other articles.
A diving suit.

I do not know about that. Surely commonsense should have some bearing on this matter, and the officials of the Department of Finance down the country who see these goods should use a little commonsense in their examination of them. It is not too much to expect them to come to some standard of commonsense. There is a large number of other voxatious details in connection with this that ought to be put right. It is annoying to people when they think the tariff is being strained too far, and they resent it. Let it be stated definitely what is and is not dutiable. Let definite articles come under the heading, and let us have a decision in law in those border cases which are reported from time to time, so that there will be no further disputes between the people to whom goods are consigned and the officials. This House made the law and they should make it clear.

I want to take up a few details here more than any question of large principle. There is the question of harbour boards and other authorities and their trading profits. The Minister said that relief could not be given in this particular case unless it was extended to the trading profits made by all local authorities and by the Electricity Supply Board. I understand that the profits of the Electricity Supply Board are already immune from that particular tax. It seems to me that the question of relieving a harbour board from income tax upon its income is not covered by the question of ordinary trading profits of a municipality. The income of a harbour board is all taken from dues and to the extent to which it is relieved would be relieved from dues, and therefore relieved from an addition which is invariably and inevitably put upon the cost of goods. Any taxation on the revenue of a harbour board is simply a direct increase in the cost of service. You can justify a tax upon coal or upon oil used for industrial purposes on exactly the same ground. A tax upon any other portion of the effective production could be justified on exactly the same ground as income taxation upon harbour board revenue. It has certain work to do, and if the Government take out of its revenues any sum of money by means of income tax then it has to get that money from other sources. It does not matter whether it is income tax deducted from the interest upon its stocks or upon what might seem nominally trade profit, the effect is exactly the same. It is a direct increase in the cost of production, in so far as the production is represented by effective transport.

MainHeading.P: The Minister has taken £180,000 of the accumulated interest of the Post Office Savings Bank. This has been accumulating over a period of years. He now proposes to take 75 per cent. of the accumulated amount of that interest as income in this particular year. Needs must, I suppose, when the devil drives, and if one were to regard that transaction alone and separate there might be something in the case which he has put up; at any rate, he has a British precedent for doing so. But, having regard to the fact that in another portion of revenue largely collected through the Post Office, that is, Savings Certificates, he told us last year that he was in arrear in his provision of interest to meet his liabilities under that head by over £400,000, it does seem very extraordinary book-keeping, to say the least of it, that he takes that asset of £180,000 and converts it into revenue this year instead of putting it to meet the liability which he has on his books of over £400,000 The principle of “heads I win and tails you lose” seems to be the Minister's method of dealing with recurrent and non-recurrent obligations. This £180,000, on any system of sound book-keeping, having regard to the fact that he owes the savings certificates people this money, ought to be put to that purpose.

The Minister has gone through the list and has told us that of the total expenditure of the country the whole lot is irreducible. Having said it is irreducible two or three times, he is quite satisfied that he has proved it is irreducible, and therefore, we must accept it and start on that basis. But absolutely no evidence of any sort, kind, or description has been given to us except his own declaration to that effect. Deputy Derrig has called attention to a very extraordinary statement made by the Minister for Finance and one of which I hope the Minister for Agriculture will take very careful note. He said:

“I think it will be agreed by most people that expenditure on the Army cannot safely be reduced below the figure at which it now stands, at any rate until the possibility of internal attack on the State has completely disappeared. Even then it is questionable whether much further reduction would be justifiable until the sanctions of international law and the institutions of the League of Nations have grown more powerful than they now are.”

Here we have a statement by the Minister for Finance that the statement made by the Minister for Agriculture as to the purpose of the Army is all nonsense. If that statement means anything, it is now a direct answer to anyone who says that any organisation in this country, due to its threat of disorder, is causing any cost under the head of the Army. The Minister for Agriculture said that Army exists only, and that £1,500,000 is paid only, because there is this threat from inside. The Minister for Finance said that even if that threat from inside was not there the expenditure would be the same. What I want the House to ask themselves is: What do they think of a Budget of £24,000,000 that is justified by a Cabinet, two members of which, in relation to an item of £1,500,000, make statements so absolutely different and then, on the face of these two absolutely contradictory justifications of the same expenditure, say it is irreducible?

As far as I can see we have to look for a third explanation of the irreducibility of this £1,500,000. That explanation, apparently, is one given by the newspaper which has as its directors practically the whole of the Front Bench opposite; that is, that an Army costing £1,500,000 is maintained for the purpose of seeing that when this particular Government goes out of power there will be left in this country a power which will assert over any Dáil which is its successor the right to see that the policy of that and all succeeding Dala shall be the policy of Ministers opposite. It is irreducible because the only guarantee they have that the policy of Cumann na nGaedheal will be maintained after Cumann na nGaedheal has disappeared is this particular Army which costs £1,500,000. That is an irreducible sum. I do not know whether the average member of Cumann na nGaedheal is willing to go into the division lobby to say that £1,500,000 should be spent in building up a military organisation here in this country which will rule the succeeding Dáil, and which will prevent the succeeding Dáil altering its policy to any policy other than that for which Cumann na nGaedheal to-day stands. That is the only justification, as far as I can see, for that £1,500,000 and that seems to be utterly inadequate. I do not think that any honest member of Cumann na nGaedheal would defend that.

The whole question of what this £1,500,000 is spent for is, apparently, absolutely in the air. And unless the three or four or twenty-four voices of Cumann na nGaedheal can come to an agreement as to what the purpose of it is, it is futile, impossible and stupid to put it forward as an organisation for which an irreducible sum of this kind should be provided.

Amongst the assets of the Government there are various things, such as shares in the Agricultural Credit Corporation, and that “Crown and Anchor” establishment called the Industrial Trust Company of Ireland. The Industrial Trust Company of Ireland was a special inspiration from heaven. Inspiration from heaven is not confined, apparently, to the Minister for Local Government. The Minister for Finance gets it also. The Industrial Trust Company of Ireland is one of “the banking institutions of a new character” which was to take the place of the effete organisations of that type in this country, and which was to do for Irish industry what the Minister for Finance, at that particular moment, did not think the existing banking institutions were doing. Into that organisation the Government put £50,000, which is included amongst their miscellaneous assets. It is included as £50,000 amongst their existing assets. What is the value of that £50,000? Of course, it is making a profit. It made a very respectable profit of £14,851 in the year ended 31st March, 1930, on a capital, I think, of £250,000. That is not at all bad. But in making up that profit it shows investments in industrial and other undertaking of £271,547. Apparently, lest the auditor might have insisted on alluding to it, there is a footnote that shows that the market value of these investments which they value at £271,547 was £199,000. In other words, they make a profit of £14,851 in that particular year by including £72,000 of assets that they had not got, and that they knew they had not got.

Now, the Government, I understand, have two representatives on that particular board. Is this the type of accounting that is shown here also in the Budget? If the Industrial Trust Company of Ireland has balanced its budget to the extent of a profit of £14,851 by including £70,000 worth of assets which they know they have not got, is that a type or sample of the finance of the Minister for Finance, who includes £50,000 worth of shares at par that he has in that company? I think we shall have another opportunity in this House—I certainly think there ought to be another opportunity in this House—in which we will go into exactly what is done, by whom it was done, when £271,000 was invested, how and where it was invested. I think it is time this House knew why £50,000 of Government money was invested in a purely gambling transaction. In the previous year, investments by this company were put down as £291,000 when they knew their value was £233,000. Then also they showed a profit.

Having regard to the finance of the subsidiary companies of the Minister for Finance, the House will not be in the least bit surprised to know that he includes amongst his assets what really are debts. He values “advances to the unemployment fund” at £563,000. Among the assets which make this country more solvent is included the fact that industries will have to be directly taxed in the future to the amount of £563,000. That is the plain meaning. He might just as well include £400,000 for a petrol tax which he has not put on. You know that is the sort of finance which gave free board and lodging to Hooley, Hatry and Whittaker Wright. There is no difference except the size of the sum.

Speaker.P: Is not Hatry too personal to your Cork friends?

I am sorry I did not hear you. I do not think I am losing much, but I want to give you an opportunity. I had, on another occasion, an opportunity of going through some of these other assets which he has laid out here. I do not propose to go through them again. You do not need to go past this one single item. If a man includes amongst his assets the assets of the State, the fact that he is to tax industry in the future he is capable of anything. National Loan Sinking Fund, unspent balance, £197,000. Last year that was £122,000. I would like to know where that is, and what has been done with it, whether it is invested, whether it is providing income, or whether it is not. At the present moment it is a very vague figure. I can quite see the Minister's position. National Loan is at such a level he does not want to buy it. I think that is quite good justification for him to say that he will wait until it is cheaper, or something of that kind, but I certainly want to know what is happening and what is being done with the £197,000 that he has. On one occasion, a very critical occasion in the credit of this country, he allowed National Loan to drop one-and-a-half points, and to remain one-and-a-half points down for five most critical days, when £7 10s. would have saved it. He had apparently £122,000 somewhere about that time. He certainly does seem to be very careful of the finances of this State when he saves £7 10s. at the cost of letting the credit of the country be depreciated at a particular moment of that kind. The Deputy from Kilkenny, Deputy Gorey, objected to the fact that the Minister for Finance has not shown common sense. He ought not to be surprised at that. Why should he ask the Minister for Finance to be exceptional among his comrades? In a particular case in the courts in which an official of the Minister for Justice was concerned, when the magistrate said that a Civic Guard should exercise common sense in the discharge of his functions, the Minister for Justice appealed to a higher court; so that, I think, Deputy Gorey will feel that perhaps he has been unjust to the Minister for Finance in suggesting that he is in any way exceptional among his comrades or in any way breaking the tradition of the Government which Deputy Gorey supports, when he failed in common sense.

MainHeading.P: The Minister tells us that he does not propose to make any definite changes in the income tax position. He apparently forgets that two years ago he gave us a promise, or an engagement, which would at any rate justify an action for breach of promise, that he would consider very favourably the proposal to exempt from income tax moneys put back into business. He has not done so now. A few days ago he suggested, in relation to the milling situation, that possibly he would deal with it by discrimination in taxation, presumably income taxation. There is no sign of that. There is no sign of what you might call a constructive method at all. It is purely and simply the book-keeping of a man who, hard driven, collects any unconsidered trifle and sells it for revenue. He takes £180,000, which he certainly has no right to take, just as in the previous year he took about £250,000 of brewers' credit, and I think about £50,000 to £100,000 of currency conversion money which does not appear this year. He balances his Budget every year on exactly the same principle that a lodger might balance his weekly budget—by selling one week his landlady's clock, and, if she did not notice it, next week his landlady's dog, eventually, no doubt, acquiring a right to free board and residence at the expense of the whole community.

The Minister for Finance performs on a larger scale exactly the same kind of function. He finds, for instance, that he has a few million pounds' worth of stock which is now giving him only interest. He sells it and regards it as income. He has done that to the extent of many millions of pounds. Some American once wrote a story. “The man who stole the National Debt.” The Minister for Finance, in the pretence of balancing his Budget for the last few years, has in fact stolen the national debt. He has put to current expenses purposes capital resources equal to what he stated to be the net national debt. No doubt, as he says now, he is coming to the end of his landlady's furniture. He will have either to live on his income or get out. I have an idea that the Minister for Finance is budgeting for a deficit next year. I think he knows what is coming to him and to those who supported him here, and he has decided to leave the cupboard absolutely bare for his successor, having sold out everything that was of movable value. This Budget is not honest. It is not as dishonest as some of the previous ones, because there was less movable property to be disposed of. When the Minister for Finance has reached the stage that there is no movable property then he will be honest and remove himself, as my friend behind says. It is not the worst of his Budgets. It would be an inspired thing if he could repeat some of his expedients in this Budget.

This Budget will not contribute in any way, as far as I can see, to the increase of any industrial activity in the country. There is no suggestion whatever of any encouragement. He has up his sleeve, which he ought to have included with the £563,000 advances to the Unemployment Fund, a petrol tax with which he hopes to buy some support in some subsequent by-elections on the pretence that he is going to de-rate. Apart from that he seems now to have reached his limit. A man with no sense of responsibility or of sound finance has now apparently reached the end of his tether. Personally, I hope the end of that tether will come soon. A Minister for Finance is not merely an accountant; he is not merely a person charged with the duty of keeping books; he is charged with the duty of organising the finance and resources of the country so as to stimulate wealth production in the country. There is no sign whatever of any such purpose or intention in this Budget.

Speaker.P: To me, at any rate, the Minister's statement yesterday in introducing the Budget was disappointing, and I am of opinion that it will be read with very great disappointment throughout the country in general. In listening to the Minister yesterday, I felt that I was listening to a tired man who had very little energy and certainly no enthusiasm to face up to the situation that exists in the country to-day. There were, in the past year at any rate, many suggestions as to how certain economies could be effected in administration. Perhaps there were so many that the Minister got bewildered and rather than face up to the situation he threw up his hands in despair and decided to leave things as they were. During the past year we have read discussions in the papers as to the taxable capacity of the people of this State. I followed the discussions as closely as I could but, unfortunately, I found myself, after I had read them, in a greater mess than before. I felt that the Minister might give some indication in his Budget statement as to what our taxable capacity is. It surely is a thing which cannot very well be passed over by Deputies. I think some authoritative statement should be made on that matter. Does the Minister for Finance hold that we have not yet reached the limit of our taxable capacity or does he think that we have overreached it? I think that matter, in a young State of this kind, should be considered. The Minister, for instance, stated that we could not expect for years to come to have social services in this State up to the standard of other countries that are longer established. That is quite reasonable, but my impression is that it is only certain social services which are of benefit to the ordinary taxpayer of this country that are to be inferior to other countries. At the same time we are to have what might be termed governmental luxuries which are far ahead of similar institutions in other countries, particularly when we take into account the wealth-producing resources of other countries compared with ours.

MainHeading.P: I think the Minister can certainly not claim as he did yesterday that he has reached the bedrock of economy as regards certain services under Government control. He stated yesterday that it was impossible to make any further economies in certain Departments. I think that before this Budget was introduced we might at least have had a report from this Economy Committee which was set up some years ago by the Government. We should at least know what they have done and if they have come to the conclusion, as stated by Mr. Blythe yesterday, that no further economies in certain services are possible and that it was wrong and might be a loss in the long run to reduce certain individuals' salaries, Ministers' or others. We had the statement by the Minister that excluding teachers, police and army, the salaried list of this State amounts to 16.5 per cent. of our total estimated expenditure, both Central Fund and Supply. I think that is rather high. I have found that it is very much higher than the estimated expenditure in at least one other State. I think the Economy Committee cannot claim to have done its duty while leaving that position as it is. Of course if we had a statement from that Committee we would know if they had considered this question and we might view it from a different standpoint altogether. I think it is unfair of the Minister to forestall the Economy Committee's report and state that he has reached the bedrock of economy in that respect. We are aware that economy is being practised very rigidly in certain services. Take for instance Old Age Pensions or the Land Commission or Public Works. I find that very rigid economy and praiseworthy economy from a Government point of view is being practised in those Departments. I could appreciate that economy very well if the same economy were practised in other Government services, but I find that the more economy they practise in services that give the greatest public assistance and that are of the greatest interest to the people, the more lavish they are in dealing out public funds to certain other petted services of the Government.

It cannot be claimed on this question of economy that the Government, by a pure accident a few years ago, when it established itself, hit the happy medium. Surely that would be too much for them to claim, and when they could have a show-down on the question of old age pensions and other matters, I think it is only reasonable for us to claim that they could have a show-down on the Departments. At least we might expect a statement from the Minister as to what economy was attempted in certain Departments, in what we claim to be overpaid services.

The chief thing which I want to emphasise in connection with the Minister's statement yesterday is the fact that for the coming year the total amount to be expended on Gaeltacht services amounts to only £87,000. This is the first time we have got the amount that is to be expended on all Gaeltacht services for the coming year. I think that is very unfair to the congested districts in the West of Ireland. If only £87,000 is to be expended in Gaeltacht services, taking into consideration the new Gaeltacht Housing Act. taking into consideration also the long-promised measure for fishery development, I do not think we can get much ahead in the coming year. My impression is that from County Mayo alone applications have already been lodged for the major portion of the money under the Gaeltacht Housing Act. Again, in the Gaeltacht services I find that there is the extraordinary amount of £37,000 —it may be a few hundred pounds more or less—to be expended in the coming year on salaries, sea fisheries protection, and travelling expenses, leaving only £50,000 for the Gaeltacht services. Surely there is something wrong there. I think that the Minister for Finance, realising that we have been promised some measure for the development of the fishery industry and that we have the Gaeltacht Housing Act already in operation, is not dealing fairly with the Gaeltacht services in the congested districts in that respect. I did expect, too, that at least the recent Government defeat in this House on a certain measure would have had some effect upon the Minister when he was preparing his Budget. Surely it is not too much for us to expect that the moral effect at least of that defeat should have been reflected in the Budget which the Minister was preparing at the time.

I think that the time should have come, at least if the Government is to learn any lesson at all, when the Minister should make some effort when introducing his Budget to come nearer to the wishes of the majority of this House and to come nearer to the requirements of the ordinary people of the country. I am of the opinion that no effort at all has been made in that respect. The Government seem always to be anxious to cater for the people who are very well able to look after themselves. You have people in the Gaeltacht and in the congested districts tied down absolutely within a very narrow margin. You have the statement that a large number of Civic Guards are to be kept in these districts to watch the people for whatever breaches of the law they may be tempted to commit. I think that, generally speaking, the Minister has made no effort whatever to extract revenue from the people in a manner which might be said to give justice to every section of the community. We have, of course, fresh taxation this year—a tax of £10 on travelling shops. That is a thing I am opposed to. If I could feel that the Minister's idea in imposing that £10 tax on lorries doing business in the country was to make some endeavour to bring back to the smaller towns what they had lost in trade I would view it from a different standpoint, but my impression is that this tax on the travelling shop will not make the least difference to the smaller towns in the West of Ireland or perhaps in any part of the country. Surely if this pays a merchant, if he is energetic enough to do business in the modern fashion as it is done in other countries, he can easily obtain by some means or other the £10 that will enable him to do so. I believe that this will be of little benefit to the business people in the towns, and that the tax is levied because it is a very simple method of collecting revenue. That is as it appears to me. It has been stated here that people were delighted when they read the Minister's statement with regard to this proposal, but I believe that it has been received with as great disappointment, and possibly with greater disappointment, than they recently received the news of the return of President Cosgrave to power.

Speaker.P: I have been wondering for some little time past during this debate what is the matter with the Cumann na nGaedheal Party, because during some of the speeches there were only two members of that Party in the House, and they were not even members of the Party; they were attached Independents. There was only one Minister present, and he was obviously interested in maps, or some other matter which had nothing to do with the subject. I have a sort of feeling of sympathy with the Minister for Finance because he received so little support from his own Party in the defence of his Budget. If his Party felt strongly in favour of his Budget they would certainly have attempted to answer the very telling criticism of it which has come from these benches. I have no doubt that Deputy Gorey will take the opportunity of defending the Budget, on which he has been so silent up to this. The only interpretation I can put upon this continued silence of the Government Party and its various sub-parties—they are in a rather indescribable condition at the moment, and I think they will be in a more indescribable condition after the next election—is that the Fianna Fáil policy of tariffs has won a complete victory, and that only the consideration of holding the Government Party together, on the principle of hanging together for fear that they might be hanged separately, has prevented them from expressing frankly their views on the question of tariffs.

MainHeading.P: The modern State must take up an attitude on economic matters quite different from the attitude taken up by States of 100 or 150 years ago. There was a time when all that a Minister for Finance had to consider was the levying of taxation for the purpose of paying for certain essential services. Now a Minister for Finance is in a different world in a sense, on account of syndicates, trusts, cartels, and so on, great companies whose turnover, whose actual income in a year even, is sometimes equal to the revenue of the State, and especially in the case of a small State, the responsibilities of a Minister for Finance extend far beyond the mere matter of levying taxation. He has to protect the individuality of that State, and the rights of the individual within that State. Most countries at present carry out that duty by way of tariffs. They protect the individual and they protect the State against the invasion of enormous economic interests which would wreck the State. Europe is full of examples of that sort of thing being done, and on the other hand, the greatest example of where it was not done was in Ireland during the nineteenth century, when absolute wreckage was created because we had not got the power of framing our own finances in such a way as would protect the economic interests of the people and of the individual.

One has only to compare the time of the Repeal Clubs when Davis had a great audience in Ireland to write for and to speak to. At that time there were in every town and village small industries which were supplying the needs of the people, such as nail-making and other small industries. The men working these industries were all independent. They had leisure, and a capacity for giving themselves in their leisure time to the interests of the nation. Because Ireland had not got the governmental machinery at that time to protect its economic interests, these industries were destroyed by the economic policy imposed by the predominant interests in England. In the actual results of government, there is no difference since 1921; there is no difference in the economic history of the wreckage of this country, there is no change from that period in the 19th century, and the Minister for Finance is largely to blame. I do not say that he is entirely to blame.

I think I have noticed indications of an attempt on his part to do the right thing, but it has been checked by other Departments. I can take a very small example of that. It was quite obvious from what the Minister said last year that he would have liked to give exemption—and this is probably one of the smallest concessions asked for—or, rather, a drawback on motor parts coming into this country which would be made into motor cars here. Such a concession as that would not have done any harm. It could not have done any harm to the revenue; it could not have done any harm to those people who are taking advantage of the protective tariff for the purpose of making the parts here, and there are a certain number of workshops scattered here and there that are making parts. But the reason given by the Minister is the worst criticism of his own attitude. He says he does not know of any companies that would do it, that it would only be done on a small scale. Well, if it was only done on a small scale it could not interfere with the other industry of making parts, it could not interfere with the amount of revenue coming into the country, while the effect would be very gradual, and when the time came if these companies found it was to their interests to buy parts made in this country, they would immediately switch over to doing so, rather than introduce the parts from other countries, because the freight would be saved, and it would be handier for them to get what they wanted on the spot. Here there was an opportunity of creating a small industry. Small industries would have sprung up in this case just as they have done in other cases where tariffs have been put on, such as furniture. The Minister, although quite satisfied to consider the matter favourably last year, apparently referred it to some other Department, which turned it down. I guess it must have been the Department of Industry and Commerce, because when I mentioned the matter yesterday he said that the application should be made to that Department.

Now, that particular application was made to that Department at least two years ago and no satisfaction was received from it. Apparently, there is some influence working which is preventing the development of small industries and which is sacrificing the individual in this country to much greater interests outside the country. Even the Government Party is apparently realising that there is something so radically wrong in the financial policy of the Government that its members are not prepared to get up in the House to defend the Minister.

It would be quite possible for two parallel Budgets to be framed by a Minister and to produce the same amount of taxation, and while one Budget would have a wrecking effect on the prosperity of the nation the other Budget, producing about the same amount of money, would have the effect of fostering industry. My criticism is not directed so much to the amount of money produced, as to the quality of the Budget. I need not go over the ground that has been gone over already. I will merely say, in a general way, that the Budget is not one to help the small man to progress, the small man with initiative who, if he had an opportunity, would remain in the country. On the other hand, you have a pathetic, hat-in-hand policy towards rich persons who left this country, or towards persons who, the Minister thinks, might come to live here. I do not object to anybody coming to live in Ireland provided he is going to carry out the duties of citizenship in a proper way. What I do object to is a policy which tends towards paying so much attention to the rich people, and which neglects the interests of the poorer people, which will not encourage the poor man with a large family by giving proper rebates on income-tax, which will not aim at developing small industries, but which, on the other hand, looks to getting revenue by reducing income tax and super tax, and thereby inducing rich people to come back to this country. A Minister for Finance should aim at improving the quality of the life of the people, should aim at distributive justice, to see that prosperity is well spread over the whole people. A happy country is a country where the people are more or less upon equal terms financially; the most unhappy country in the world is the country where there is a small class with an enormous amount of riches, and a large class with very little of the goods of this world.

No doubt the Minister is handicapped by the fact that an important portion of the area of taxation of this country is excluded from his jurisdiction. There are six counties from which the Minister can draw no taxation. Taxation has been levied on the Six Counties amounting to £10,000,000. If, under the one Government, the cost of governing these six counties could not add more than we will say—and this is making a generous estimate—an extra £5,000,000, that would leave for the benefit of the country £5,000,000, or we will say less than £5,000,000. At any rate it would be a considerable relief and would afford opportunities for a great reduction in taxation. It is important in these debates always to remind the Minister of the economic effects of partition. Goods coming through Belfast, and coming down here, must necessarily in price be subject to double taxation. Ultimately, the consumer is the person who pays a very large proportion of all taxes. The person who handles the goods coming through Belfast has to pay a certain amount of tax. What that person pays asserts itself in the price of the goods coming through. The person selling the goods here must allow, consciously or unconsciously for the tax, and so the consumer has to bear, in the price that he pays for the goods, this double taxation. I do not know whether the Minister is likely to make any general change in policy, but certainly the country will not be able to stand, for another five years this completely negative policy for which he and his party have been hitherto responsible.

Speaker.P: I am not in the least disappointed in the Minister's Budget this year because I expected nothing else. I did not expect that he was going to do anything whatsoever for the agricultural community. I had hoped, when I saw Deputy Gorey getting up, that he was going to make some appeal for the party which he once represented in this House, namely the Farmers' Party. I do not know exactly what Deputy Gorey represents now, for he changed from the Farmers' Party and joined the Cumann na nGaedheal Party, but lo and behold! to-day apparently on account of a new alliance he spoke from the Front Labour Benches.

Apparently he has now become a Labour representative. I do not know whether the Labour Party is to be congratulated or not, but I was amazed when I heard no word from Deputy Gorey with regard to the present position of the farming community, no appeal from him that the farming community should at least be placed in as favourable a position as their colleagues and fellow-farmers across the Border. Deputy Gorey was only concerned to-day with cricket. I can easily picture Deputy Gorey marching down Grafton Street in white duck trousers, with shin guards and rubber gloves and canvas shoes and a yellow shirt. I think the Minister for Finance and the customs officials ought to be congratulated in saving us from that.
Do not forget his red flower.

I think the Minister ought to be congratulated in saving us from that. Last year I made an appeal to the Minister for Finance to look for revenue from the large amount of agricultural produce that is brought into this country. But, apparently, those who paid so freely to the election fund of Cumann na nGaedheal and who are expected to pay freely in the future have a right to call the tune. Messrs. Guinness, for instance, who in the year 1928 imported into this country barley to the value of £120,000, in the year 1929 imported barley to the value of £220,000—an increase of £100,000 worth on the quantity of barley they imported the year previous. That barley is brought in here to compete against the barley which the Irish farmer produces. The Minister for Finance, apparently, was put in here by the funds of Guinness and his crowd to stand by and not attempt to put a tariff on foreign barley that is brought in here to compete against what the Irish farmer produces. I suppose that is only what we are to expect.

The Minister for Finance has thrown out one sop, one sprat, to catch the mackerel in Longford-Westmeath. He tells us that he is holding over the tax on petrol until he gets the result of the De-rating Commission. That is the sop that he is throwing out to the farmers of Longford and Westmeath to swallow. I noticed that when the Farmers' Union Party made their case at the De-rating Commission they did not put forward one single plea——
We are not concerned with what was put before the De-rating Commission. It does not arise on this Budget at all.
I intend to put forward here the case that should have been put forward by the farmers there.
The Deputy cannot do that.

I intend to refer now to sources of revenue that the Minister for Finance might turn to when looking for funds to de-rate the farmers of the country. In the year 1929 we imported bacon into this country to the value of £1,627,000. This morning I met one of the farmers' representatives in this House—Deputy White. He was bewailing the price that he was getting for potatoes. We all know very well that at the present time you cannot get anything like a price for potatoes in the Twenty-six Counties. The Ulster farmers, however, are alive to the situation. In the year 1928 they imported £39,000 worth of potatoes across the Border, while the figure this year is £65,000. The farmers across the Border who have no rates to pay and whose annuities go to the relief of taxation can send potatoes to the value of £65,000 across the Border to compete with the potatoes that are grown by our farmers who have to pay their land annuities over to John Bull through the generosity of the Minister for Finance, as well as £67,000 for collecting them, and, in addition, £2,100,000 a year in rates. Why does not our Minister for Finance say that he will put 4/- in the £ on potatoes coming in here across the Border, and let that go to the relief of the taxation the farmers have to pay? He will not do that. That, as he would say, would prevent the North from coming in some day. In 1929 we imported butter into this country to the value of £360,000. We all know that butter is a drug on the market at the present day. Despite that, in February of this year £34,000 worth of butter was imported into the Free State. The Minister for Finance has made no attempt whatever to put a tariff on foreign butter coming in here.

MainHeading.P: We are looking for sources of revenue. There are plenty of sources of revenue. £7,249,000 worth of agricultural produce comes into this country every year. There is a source of revenue in that. Two shillings in the £ on that imported agricultural produce would yield £780,000, which could go towards de-rating. That imported produce is, of course, in competition with what we produce here, and the revenue which would be derived from a tax upon it would enable the Minister to make some provision for the relief of the farmers of this country. Apparently the Minister for Finance is going to hang on until the farmers are down and out, and in fact they are already down and out. He considers that when he has gagged the six farmers here with a job he can do what he likes with the farming community. It is time the Minister was brought to his senses. The importation of agricultural produce into this unfortunate country is a scandal, and worse than a scandal. If the Irish farmer exported his butter to Australia, the Minister knows the tariff he would have to pay on the butter going into that country. Still Australia, New Zealand and Canadian butter is brought in here and put into competition with the butter in the home market without a single attempt by the Minister for Finance to prevent it.

We heard a lot about economy from the Minister for Finance when he was speaking on the Budget. Apparently he thinks it is right that the gentlemen with £1,500 a year should have a war bonus of £206, to help them to live, out of the pockets of the unfortunate farmer, who has to work and slave and drag to keep body and soul together at present. Then we have the Department of External Affairs costing about £58,000, and the expenditure upon which is gradually increasing. What is it for? What do these ambassadors abroad represent?

Speaker.P: The Deputy knows that Estimate was dealt with by the House and he cannot go into it again.
Yes. I would like to ask the Minister for Finance only one question. Is he aware that the flag floating over this House was made in Liverpool?
Perhaps Deputy Corry will sit down. The Deputy will have to obey the Chair. He has been told he will not be allowed to deal with any Estimate which has been dealt with by the House already.

I do not intend dealing with any of these Estimates if I am not allowed to deal with one in particular. All I have to say is that the manner in which this money is being expended is a scandal, and the manner in which the farming community are being treated by this House is a bigger scandal still. If the Minister for Finance was back where he was in 1914, travelling in Cork county, and if he visited the farmers whose hospitality he enjoyed in 1914 and 1915, he would realise that at present they cannot afford to put even a plate of butter before him. He should realise that he has starved those farmers out of existence, and he need not think that because he has gagged the so-called Farmers' Party here he is going to be allowed to get away with it, for he is not. If the Minister is not prepared to come forward to the relief of the farming community to put them in at least the same financial position or give them the same opportunity of competing even in our home market with those people who have no rates to pay and whose annuities go to the relief of taxation, then let him get out, for the farming community in the country will not allow themselves to be squeezed out by him. They have been long enough the hewers of wood and the drawers of water for all the pensioners the Minister for Finance has piled upon us for the last five years. It is about time he realised the position. I have no doubt we will find that in Longford-Westmeath they are working overtime to produce a new lot of Army pensioners—buckshee generals who will have to be pensioned, and we will have something on the lines of the Monaghan scandal that was exposed here a short time ago. It is time that was stopped. We are not going to allow the farming community to work and slave in order that the Minister may turn out a few gentlemen with a gratuity of £3,000 and £300 a year, and if he is not going to stop it here we will get other means to stop it.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. B. Maguire Mr. B. Maguire
Speaker.P: One of the disappointments in the Budget speech to me was the statement that no further reduction in the way of expenditure was possible. Having regard to the fact that we have had statements made in the House from time to time by the Minister for Agriculture that further progress in the development of the farming community was not to be anticipated, and that a somewhat similar statement was made by the Minister for Industry and Commerce so far as his Department is concerned, I think the Minister's Budget statement must have very serious consequences. In the earlier years when Budgets were introduced here we were buoyed up with the hope that perhaps development in the industrial prosperity of the country would enable us to meet the exorbitant demands of the Budgets. Our Ministers have had seven or eight years of experience in the administration of their Departments, and it is disappointing to get from them the statements we have had. It is a disappointment to hear from the Minister for Agriculture that there is no possibility of the development of agriculture along the lines which he has advocated since he took up office. Suggestions have been made outside the House, which I think have received support from this and smaller Parties in the House, that a change of policy in the Department of Agriculture is desirable.

MainHeading.P: To the advocacy of increased tillage and a departure from the present policy of the production of commodities for export, the Minister for Agriculture and the majority Party here have consistently been in opposition. They have refused to listen to reasonable argument which advocates a change of their policy. Without alteration, they have stuck to the theories put forward by the Minister for Agriculture. The only solution, according to the Minister, for the development of the agricultural industry, is along the lines he indicates. These lines have, from time to time, involved the people of the country in taxation amounting to a very considerable sum. Above all other things, the Minister strongly recommended and secured the support of the House for the development of creameries, and the result is that the people of the country, during the last five or six years, found themselves in the unfortunate position that they had to expend a considerable sum in capital expenditure. In view of the depreciated conditions the farmers are left in a very insecure position. The circumstances which have faced us here within the last few years show clearly that the policy advocated by the Government has never been a sound policy. Even the Government's own supporters cannot honestly regard it as a satisfactory policy.

Similarly, any progress in the way of industrial development is handicapped. In my part of the country there are mineral resources which are capable of producing great wealth. Since my earliest days I have heard of the possibilities of these mineral resources. Many men have spoken of the wealth that could be produced from those mineral resources under proper management. I was present at a meeting at which the President of the Executive Council spoke, and he referred to those mineral resources as possessing wonderful prospects for the country as a whole. For years I have been looking forward to the time when those mineral resources would be utilised for the advancement of the country, and I was never more disappointed than during the last three or four weeks, when I found that the Department of Industry and Commerce had definitely turned down any hopes that existed of utilising the mineral deposits in that part of the country. They apparently regard the whole thing as a fallacy, for they have discarded the railway line put down by the British Government in 1918 at an expenditure of £50,000. The railway line was connected with the locality in which the mineral deposits lie. That method of transport was regarded by the Department of Industry and Commerce as unnecessary. The railway line was lifted, and all hope of developing our mineral resources there—resources which the President of the Executive Council referred to ten or twelve years ago and had great prospects in mind for —has been shattered.

We have these two Departments of State going on wrong lines, and I think the time has come when some change of policy should be introduced. The Department of Agriculture is operating along the lines advocated by the Minister as essential lines of progress. Practical experience of those lines has proved that the farmers are up against a solid rock and many of them have been brought to the position that they are handicapped by overhead charges which they will not be able to bear in view of the depreciated prices. We find that the possibility of industrial development is negatived, as instanced in the case I have given of the mineral resources of Leitrim, which were at one time regarded as a practical certainty and which were put forward as one strong reason why we should fight for independence so that our immense natural resources could be developed to the country's advantage. The responsible authorities here have withdrawn all transport facilities and definitely put an end to any hope of utilising the resources there.

Since there is no possibility of expansion in the matter of agriculture or industrial development, is it not time that the Minister for Finance cut his coat according to his cloth and reduced his enormous Budget? He should realise that this is a poor country. His Budgets in past years have been responsible for driving into bankruptcy many business men, and surely he should cease to continue along the road that has meant bankruptcy for business people. His policy has also affected other sections of the community to the extent that they find it hard now to exist. One hope that the Minister for Finance held out yesterday was that by keeping the income tax low the richer elements would be encouraged to come back to this country. He believed that people who had never been here would come to live here by reason of the lower income tax. I will add my voice to the numerous voices raised on this side of the House and I will say that if that is the only inspiration the Minister for Finance had when he was preparing his Budget —that by keeping the income tax at a lower level than in England rich men would be induced to come to live in this country—then he has very clearly declared his policy. I think that the Minister should have taken up a totally different attitude. He should have considered the possibility of developing our resources and he should have considered the interests of the working man, the business man and the farmer as of far more importance than the holding out of any baits to be given at the expense of the people in order to encourage outsiders to come to live here.

Speaker.P: Deputies have suggested that a Budget which does not contain great changes in taxation indicates a negative economic policy. That suggestion arises apparently from the belief that some Deputies on the other side of the House must hold, that by changing taxation about the troubles which this country, in common with other countries suffer from can be cured. I admit that harm can be done by placing a particular load of taxation in a particular way, and some good may be done by placing the same load of taxation in another way. But the benefits that can be got from changes in taxation are, relatively, small and indirect. They are benefits in the way of giving opportunities to individuals who are in charge of industries, or who may take charge of industries, to develop and expand those industries. The policy of the Government in regard to tariffs, as opposed to the policy of the Fianna Fáil Party in regard to tariffs, is well known and I do not think I need go into it again. But I would just like to deny what members on the other side have asserted by implication, at least, that because some particular employment that might be given if there were a high tariff is not being given in consequence of that tariff not having been imposed, a national loss has necessarily resulted.

MainHeading.P: Deputy O'Reilly quoted me as having said that tariffs are an investment. I do not remember the occasion on which I said that, but I am quite prepared to say that tariffs are an investment. And some tariffs may be a bad investment, a very bad investment, and not to be justified. Almost all tariffs, and tariffs in the bulk, are an investment in the sense that expenditure has to be incurred in order to attain an end. Tariffs will give us increased employment. Tariffs, broadly speaking, impose extra charges on the people. Any extra charge is liable to decrease production and employment somewhere else. Any charge of a substantial nature is bound to decrease employment and production. What we feel has to be weighed in relation to any tariff, where it can be weighed, is whether or not the employment that will be given as a result of that tariff will or will not be outweighed by the loss of employment which will result from the burden that that tariff is likely to throw on the people. I have admitted that, in certain cases, tariffs impose no burden on the people. In that respect, the tariffs on cigarettes and tobacco and others can be mentioned; but, broadly speaking, the position is that tariffs throw a burden on the people and that burden decreases production and employment. On the other hand, the tariff causes employment in the industry to which it is applied. The mere fact that some employment has been lost in a particular industry or that there has been a failure to give employment in a particular industry because a tariff was not imposed does not necessarily prove that there was any national loss at all in that respect.

Deputy MacEntee asked what was the present value of the items representing advances to the Electricity Supply Board and expenditure on the Shannon scheme. I believe the present value is par. I believe that, if we were prepared to dispose of the Shannon scheme to a private corporation to be run as a business concern, the money that has been expended in connection with it could be got at the purchase price. It is true that the shannon scheme——

Speaker.P: May I interrupt the Minister to ask would not that presuppose that the purchasing corporation would have the same monopoly powers as the present Supply Board, so that you would be selling not your investment but your monopoly rights, for which you do not take any credit at all?

Monopoly rights to be included in a certain purchase price. In my opinion, the assets represented by these figures may be taken at the amount at which I give them. There might be, in respect of some of the minor items, some small depreciation, but in the big figures the actual value is not less than the value represented by the figures, and there is nothing that would materially alter the total. Deputy MacEntee asked why I did not include the capital value represented by the land annuities in my statement with regard to debt. I did not include it because the liability in respect of land annuities is a contingent liability. If I had included it, it would not have altered the net total, because against the capital value on the one side would have been set the aggregate of the advances owed by the farmers, and the position would not have been altered. So far as the local loans are concerned, if they had been included and if any change had been made, the change would have been by way of reducing the figure of the net debt, because the capitalised value of the £600,000, which is payable for twenty years, is less than the value of the loans outstanding on the other side, which have not been taken into account. The position would not, if I had included these figures, have been altered. The figures of the net debt certainly would not have been increased. The Deputy asked why a capital sum to represent certain pensions was not included in the figures of liabilities. That would be completely absurd. As I pointed out to somebody in the Seanad who raised the same question, you might as well put a figure in for the capital value of the old age pensions which are at present being paid. To put in a capital figure in your total debt to represent pension liabilities would be preposterous. Deputy MacEntee said that he wanted to make life as attractive here for the young people as it is in other countries. That is contrary to the policy of his great leader, who wants the hair-shirt policy, another standard of life, and to put a stone or a brass wall around the country
So the Minister says.

Well, most people so understood his words, and he certainly indicated that we were not to have the standards of life here that people have in other countries. If we are not to have the same standards of life as people have in other countries, I do not see how we can make life as attractive here for the young people as it is elsewhere. The task of doing that, as I hope Deputy MacEntee realises, is a very great task, and it is one which involves, not some further loading of productivity with charges for new social services, but the development of industry and agricultural production here. Things that are necessary to make life attractive here cannot be got without adding on charges for social services. In all countries in the world, as a matter of fact, we have the tendency to fly from rural areas to the cities. One of the attractions of life in other countries that take our young people away is their urban character. If we are to take this aspiration of Deputy MacEntee in its full sense, one of the ways to make life in this country as attractive for young people as it is for young people in other countries would be to provide urban life and urban employment for them. The task that Deputy MacEntee says that we must discharge, and which I say is a task which we ought to have before us and discharge as well and rapidly as may be, is a very big task indeed. It is not a task that is going to be solved by any attempt to get out of paying liabilities which are justly due. It is not going to be solved by any attempt to hold on to land annuities which are at present being paid by the farmers of the Free State in return for the advances received by them. I do not say, if we could get away with something like that, that the money might not be spent here in very many useful ways, but I assert, as I have asserted outside, that there is not the slightest chance of our being able to avoid it, that there are means of enforcing the payment of debts justly due by us. There are easy means of doing that, and we would suffer what any person suffers who is called upon to pay a just debt and will not pay it. He is ultimately obliged to pay with costs added. I am satisfied that that would be the result of the attempt to stop the payment which Deputy MacEntee says should be stopped.

Deputy MacEntee also referred to expenditure on the Army and another Deputy referred to that expenditure also and to the development of the reserve and other forms of defence than a standing army. He seemed to think that getting the defence force on to a volunteer basis would of itself mean a great decrease in the present figure. I do not think that it would. It would not mean anything like the big decrease which the Deputy who talked about it had in mind. It would not avoid the expenditure on buildings or other overhead charges. It might, in fact, mean a greater expenditure on buildings and in other directions. With regard to the use of the Army, apart from the protection of the State against internal attack. I think it is clear that just as an army of a small country cannot beat an army of a big country, an army of a small country can be in a position, as armies of small countries have been before, to offer resistance which would rob of attraction an attack on that small country. That is all that the army of any small country can do, and most small countries do not think it wise at present to depend merely on the good international morals of their neighbours.

MainHeading.P: Deputy Lemass referred to a statement which I made last year that there would be very few items for segregation as abnormal or nonrecurrent except the amount that would be advanced to the Local Loans Fund. I hoped last year that still more rapid progress than has been made would have been made with the discharge of the remaining liabilities in respect of compensation. When that liability in respect of compensation during the troubled times has been disposed of, when the reconstruction of public buildings that were destroyed during those years has been completed, for all practical purposes nothing will remain in this list of deducted items except the advances to the Local Loans Fund or other items that are repayable, in so far as they may be repayable, such as expenditure on the improvement of estates by the Land Commission. It is perfectly true that you could always find abnormal items which would not recur but which would be replaced in subsequent years by similar items. There are a great number of such items in the Estimates for this year. I have not picked them out. I have continued, in so far as they remain in the Estimates, those items which were segregated in former years, with one exception, namely, the new broadcasting station.

I selected it because we are getting, and will get, out of broadcasting reception enough money to pay for the running of that station, for the programme, and for depreciation. If we had not a broadcasting station I do not think that we could continue to charge these particular taxes. We certainly could hardly charge the licence duty, and when the import duty on wireless apparatus was first imposed the opinion of the whole House was that it should be devoted to a better broadcasting service. I undertook, as soon as plans could be made, that we would devote it to that purpose. Because of that undertaking, which was desired by the Dáil and given by me, there is enough revenue arising out of broadcasting to pay for the station and the running of it, and I have set it down as a capital item. Subject to the fact that the time may be a little longer than I anticipated, the position remains that in a very short time there will be little remaining for segregation as abnormal, except advances like those to the Local Loans Fund which will go to local authorities, which are repayable by them, and which certainly ought to be provided by borrowing and not by raising taxation.

There is another item which I should mention, namely, the expenditure on forestry. The best information that we can get is that forestry, with the rates of interest as they are at present, is about half economic. If the rates of interest were about half what they are at present, forestry would be an economic proposition. Acting on that information, I have deducted half the cost of creating State woodlands as capital expenditure which might be borrowed, the other half, representing the uneconomic factor in forestry, being met out of revenue. Deputy Lemass referred again to champagne, earls, millionaires and sycophancy. We are not afraid of any development of sycophancy in this country. I do not think that there is any natural disposition among our people towards sycophancy. There are people who can be polite and civil to strangers without being corrupted and without being demoralised or denationalised by them. As I say, I do not think that there is the slightest danger of a development in that direction.

Deputy Shaw asked when the new Betting Bill would be introduced. It has already been partly drafted. Its completion was really delayed by pressure in connection with the Greater Dublin Bill and the Vocational Education Bill, but I think that the draftsman will shortly be able to give his attention to it and to complete it. With regard to the tax on bets laid with bookmakers on race courses, I do not know whether the recommendation made a year ago does not require reconsideration in view of the introduction of the totalisator. In any event, the totalisator will have to pay to the Exchequer two-and-a-half per cent. on bets made with it. I do not know whether there is any case for exempting a bookmaker who is competing with the totalisator from paying the two-and-a-half per cent. tax towards the State.

Returning again to the remarks of Deputy Lemass, I admit that the completion of the report on the application for the coach-building tariff was delayed by the fact that the Tariff Commission took up the Grain Inquiry. It had been hoped that the delay would not be as great as it proved to be. It was unfortunate, but I do not think it would have been easy to find a body as suitable for the Grain Inquiry, which was a matter of consequence, as the Tariff Commission.

Deputy Derrig and other Deputies spoke as if we had reduced income tax with a view to inducing people of wealth to return to the country or to come to it for the first time. That is an entirely incorrect assumption, and it is an assumption, for which nothing that I have said can be held responsible. There is no question of lowering income tax this year at all. The question that arose was a question of raising the standard rate for certain reasons. When we reduced income tax to 3/- in the £, we reduced it with a view to stimulating industry and stimulating the employment of money in business and in industry here, in the hope of ultimately getting greater production and greater employment. We hoped to get a direct benefit for certain industries and businesses, and for those industries and businesses which would not obtain a direct benefit we hoped to get a certain indirect benefit by an increase of confidence and by some stimulation of enterprise. When the income tax was reduced to 3/-, we had no idea of what the British tax would be in the same year, because our Budget was introduced that year before the British Budget. We had no idea that it would be reduced that year or subsequently.

To induce people to come in here was not our object. It was before us previously, when we made certain adjustments in connection with death duties and in connection with super tax, but when we found our income tax was lower than the British tax we realised that, to some extent at least, the difference would certainly bring people here. Now that the difference is greater, we believe that its effect will be greater and that more people may come in and bring capital, spending power and revenue-producing capacity with them. We do not want to reduce the effect that that difference might have by altering the rate at the present stage. Amongst other things, in order that the possibility of such people coming in may not be diminished, we do not want to raise the tax at the present time.

We do not want to raise the tax, either, because we believe that on the business psychology, which is undoubtedly pessimistic in this country, the raising of the standard rate would have a bad effect and would tend to reduce enterprise. Our object in connection with income-tax has been really to get industry and employment here, recognising that employment cannot be produced to any great extent by the State and that if we want the State to give employment we have to get another organisation altogether. We would want to get fundamental alterations for which there is no demand and no support in the country. If employment has to be provided by private individuals or companies then we wish to create an atmosphere in which there will be the greatest activity possible. Deputy Derrig drew our attention to Australian precedents. I do not know whether every difficulty which they have in Australia has been solved by what they have done. Deputy Derrig would lead us to think that if we had introduced high tariffs everything would be lovely.

Deputy Gorey asked about the scope of the apparel duty. I think there is no doubt that gloves are apparel and that the duty must be charged on them. The other articles may seem to be in the nature of borderline cases, but it is for the Revenue Commissioners, after legal advice, to judge. Their decision can be tested in the courts if anybody feels strongly enough about it to test it. Subject to interpretation by the courts, the interpretation of the scope of tariffs, like tariffs on wearing apparel, is a question for the Revenue Commissioners, having obtained legal advice on the matter.
